title: More Massachusetts residents say their finances are in poor shape, UMass poll finds
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: UMass/WCVB poll shows 21% of Massachusetts residents rate their finances as 'poor', highest since 2021.
Housing, economy, and cost of living are top financial concerns for Massachusetts residents according to the survey.
64% of respondents support keeping the current Massachusetts state flag, despite recent finalist suggestions for a new design.

title: Fitchburg police defend actions during ICE arrest after man appears to seize while holding child
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Fitchburg police maintained public safety during a chaotic ICE arrest involving a man who appeared to have a seizure.
Homeland Security's Tricia McLaughlin stated emergency medical personnel found no medical concerns during the ICE operation.
Juliana Milena Ojeda-Montoya was arrested in Fitchburg on immigration charges; her husband and child were released.

title: Review & setlist: At the Shubert, Robert Plant’s quest to keep evolving was on full display
author: Marc Hirsh
bullets: Robert Plant performed with Suzi Dian at Boston's Shubert Theatre for the 'Saving Grace' tour on November 6, 2025.
The setlist included songs from Led Zeppelin and covers by artists like Neil Young, along with new band compositions.
Rockabilly artist Rosie Flores opened the concert with a set highlighting her upright bass and twangy guitar style.

title: Are AI hiring tools to blame for job seekers being ghosted? Experts say itâ€™s more complicated.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: AI tools are used in recruiting but aren't the main cause of job seekers being ghosted, experts say.
The usage of AI in hiring is primarily as a filtering tool to manage large volumes of applications.
A cooling job market has contributed to longer hiring processes, making it more challenging for job seekers.

title: Red Sox ace Garrett Crochet and wife Rachel announce birth of first child
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Red Sox pitcher Garrett Crochet and wife Rachel welcomed their first child, Colette Spencer Crochet, announced via Instagram.
Garrett Crochet, a University of Tennessee alum, moved to Boston in 2024 and has a husky named Moose.
Crochet led the AL in innings pitched and strikeouts, and was a Cy Young Award finalist in his first Red Sox season.

title: Local obituary: Bruce Higgins, 51, West Roxbury dad, prolific youth sports coach, and Boston cop
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Bruce Higgins Jr., 51, of West Roxbury, passed away on November 2, 2025, after a six-year battle with Melanoma.
Higgins was a Boston police officer and coached various youth sports, influencing many in the Parkway community.
Bruce is survived by his wife Lori, children Madelyn and Ryan. Funeral services are on November 10, 2025.

title: MSPCA-Angell appeals for help as pet food demand surges during SNAP hold
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: The MSPCA-Angell reports a surge in pet food demand due to a hold on SNAP benefits.
Funding for SNAP ended November 1, forcing MSPCA-Angell to expand operations in Lawrence and Boston.
The nonprofit plans to increase pet meal distributions by 22,000 meals weekly, costing an additional $6,000 per week.

title: GBH lays off 15 employees in fourth wave of cuts this year
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: GBH laid off 15 employees this week, marking the fourth round of layoffs this year, due to financial challenges.
President Susan Goldberg attributed the layoffs to loss of federal funding, affecting content and back-office roles.
GBH aims to raise $225 million over three years after federal funding was cut by pressure from President Trump.

title: Police: Uber driver strangled with wire, carjacked in Boston
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: An Uber driver in Boston was allegedly strangled with a wire and carjacked on Thursday evening.
Police used the Uber driver's phone in the car to track and arrest suspect Christopher Dawkins in Dorchester.
Dawkins faces charges including carjacking, strangulation, assault, and larceny; he's set for arraignment in Boston Municipal Court.

title: ‘It was obvious’: Lucas Giolito not surprised Red Sox didn’t extend him qualifying offer
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Red Sox chose not to extend a $22.05 million qualifying offer to pitcher Lucas Giolito, citing injury concerns.
Giolito missed the Red Sox's Wild Card Series after experiencing elbow soreness following the regular season.
Despite declining a $19 million mutual option, Giolito expressed interest in re-signing with the Red Sox.
